abstract: Scientists have produced fertility in genetically infertile mice by transplanting a gene from normal animals.   All the mice that received copies of the transplanted gene turned out to be fertile. Similar mice that lacked the added genes were infertile and did not mate, according to the research. The gene was a blueprint essential for the body's production of two key brain hormones that are vital to normal sexual development and fertility.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have produced fertility in genetically infertile mice by transplanting a gene from normal animals.

headline.main: GENE TRANSPLANT CAUSES FERTILITY
headline.print_headline: GENE TRANSPLANT CAUSES FERTILITY

abstract: The Government's most prestigious advisory panel on genetic engineering proposed today a change in national safety guidelines that would remove from special scrutiny experiments of a kind that have produced major controversies in recent years.   The controversies have arisen over proposed experiments in which certain bacteria and viruses, altered by deliberate deletion of single genes, would be released outside the laboratory.   In its vote today the National Institutes of Health's Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee said such genetic deletions and minor rearrangements should no longer be subject to special scrutiny by the committee just because the deletions were achieved by gene splicing or genetic engineering methods. The procedures are known formally as recombinant DNA technology.
lead_paragraph: The Government's most prestigious advisory panel on genetic engineering proposed today a change in national safety guidelines that would remove from special scrutiny experiments of a kind that have produced major controversies in recent years.

headline.main: PANEL URGES RELAXATION IN GENETIC SPLICING RULES
headline.print_headline: PANEL URGES RELAXATION IN GENETIC SPLICING RULES

abstract: Biology has entered a golden age. Students today live in a world with test-tube babies, synthetic vaccines, miracle crops and cloned mice. On the horizon are such developments as supercows and magic-bullet cancer cures.   In tinkering with the molecules of life, biologists have helped set in motion a virtual transformation of American society. Pundits say we are experiencing a ''cultural mutation'' that is leading to a science-based ''postindustrial society.'' In the face of such monumental change, what's a biology teacher to do?   According to experts on science education, a growing number of instructors at the high school and college levels have dropped traditional methods of teaching biology. Various ''new biology'' curriculums are being used instead throughout the nation. But the transformation is still slow.
lead_paragraph: Biology has entered a golden age. Students today live in a world with test-tube babies, synthetic vaccines, miracle crops and cloned mice. On the horizon are such developments as supercows and magic-bullet cancer cures.

headline.main: NEW DIRECTIONS IN BIOLOGY
headline.print_headline: NEW DIRECTIONS IN BIOLOGY

abstract: Human gene therapy, a long awaited way to cure some of the most terrible hereditary diseases, is coming ever closer to practical reality, but there are still important problems to be solved, a panel of experts said today.   Three scientists gave an overview of current research at a meeting here of the Federal advisory committee whose approval is needed for any future experimental treatment in patients by American scientists. Addressing the National Institutes of Health's Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee were Dr. A. Dusty Miller of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, Dr. David W. Martin Jr., research vice president of Genentech Inc., the San Francisco, Calif., biotechnology company, and Dr. Robertson Parkman of Los Angeles Children's Hospital.   In gene therapy, doctors would transplant copies of a normal gene into cells of a patient whose own body lacks that gene or has it only in a malfunctioning form.   Foreign genes have been transplanted successfully into animals. Recently scientists have even cured a hereditary form of dwarfism in mice by transplanting genes for growth hormone. But this research is done by a method that is not contemplated for human gene therapy.
lead_paragraph: Human gene therapy, a long awaited way to cure some of the most terrible hereditary diseases, is coming ever closer to practical reality, but there are still important problems to be solved, a panel of experts said today.

headline.main: HEREDITARY DISEASE: NEW THERAPIES ARE CLOSER
headline.print_headline: HEREDITARY DISEASE: NEW THERAPIES ARE CLOSER

byline.original: By Harold M. Schmeck Jr., Special To the New York Times

abstract: Magnified 400 times on the television monitor, the hollow needle glides forward to touch a living cell, pierces its surface and slides deep inside.   ''There you go,'' says Myrna E. Trumbauer, a microbiologist at the University of Pennsylvania, twisting microscope knobs gently so the needle impales a tiny sphere within the cell. She pulls the needle back slightly and squirts clear liquid inside.   The cell, appearing about the size of a dime on the television screen, is the fertilized egg cell of an ordinary female mouse. It will be transplanted into the uterus of another ordinary mouse, where it will grow into a fetus and be born 21 days later in the ordinary way. The mouse pup looks ordinary too, but it will grow to twice normal size because its cells carry many copies of the gene for human growth hormone.
lead_paragraph: Magnified 400 times on the television monitor, the hollow needle glides forward to touch a living cell, pierces its surface and slides deep inside.

headline.main: IN THE GENE LAB, SCIENTISTS MANIPULATE CODES OF LIFE
headline.print_headline: IN THE GENE LAB, SCIENTISTS MANIPULATE CODES OF LIFE

byline.original: By Harold M. Schmeck Jr., Special To the New York Times

abstract: A PAINFULLY THIN young man sits in a hospital wheelchair with his legs and torso oddly twisted - as though he has been flung there. Strapped on his arms are heavily padded splints, which are there to protect him against himself. Without them he is likely to bite and horribly injure his fingers because of an uncontrollable urge to mutilate himself.   Dean La Zar has a good memory, a sense of humor, the normal hopes and fears and even some of the ambitions of a 22-year-old. He also has a rare hereditary disorder called Lesch-Nyhan disease, for which there has never been any cure, effective treatment or much hope.   Self-mutilation is one of the most mysterious hallmarks of the disease. Other bizarre quirks of behavior include the compulsive use of four-letter words, spitting at people and vomiting. The behavior varies from patient to patient and from time to time. Some have tried to poke their own eyes out with pencils or have chewed off their own lips. Terrified of their own compulsion, patients often ask to be restrained.
lead_paragraph: A PAINFULLY THIN young man sits in a hospital wheelchair with his legs and torso oddly twisted - as though he has been flung there. headline.main: A Step Closer to Gene Transplants
headline.print_headline: IDEAS & TRENDS;   A Step Closer to Gene Transplants

abstract: National guidelines were approved today for a revolutionary type of medical treatment known as gene therapy, to be used on humans against a range of fatal hereditary diseases.   The treatment involves transplanting genes, which are the body's basic blueprints for cell construction, to correct genetic defects that cause these illnesses.      Months of Discussion   Today's approval by a Government advisory panel, came after more than seven months of discussion and public comment.   Under the guidelines, each case in which gene therapy is proposed must still be approved by local review committees and the Federal Government.
lead_paragraph: National guidelines were approved today for a revolutionary type of medical treatment known as gene therapy, to be used on humans against a range of fatal hereditary diseases.

abstract: International    An opening of foreign markets to American goods is the main objective of a new program announced by President Reagan. The program would provide subsidies for some exports and put pressure on other governments to drop what the Reagan Administration criticizes as unfair trade barriers. [Page A1, Column 6.]    The dollar plunged to its lowest level in 16 months - for its largest one-day drop in the 12-year history of floating currency rates - as traders predicted that major governments would take sterner action to depress the American currency. The dollar's plunge was a clear sign that bankers were taking seriously the announcement on Sunday that the United States, Japan, Britain, West Germany and France would intervene in foreign-exchange markets and adjust their economic policies to try to push the dollar down. [A1:4-5.]

abstract: IN THE NAME OF EUGENICS. Genetics and the Uses of Human Heredity. By Daniel J. Kevles. 426 pages. Knopf. $22.95. AT a superficial glance, one might judge the subject of eugenics to be a dead one.   After all - as Daniel J. Kevles points out in the preface to ''In the Name of Eugenics'' - though the word was coined in 1883 from the Greek root meaning ''good in birth'' or ''noble in heredity,'' it came in time to have extremely ugly connotations.
lead_paragraph: IN THE NAME OF EUGENICS. Genetics and the Uses of Human Heredity. By Daniel J. Kevles. 426 pages. Knopf. $22.95. AT a superficial glance, one might judge the subject of eugenics to be a dead one.

headline.main: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
headline.print_headline: ANSWERS TO QUIZ

abstract: The first national guidelines for the conduct of human gene therapy have been published by the National Institutes of Health and are expected to have an immediate effect on research groups preparing for tests of this revolutionary form of treatment.   The therapy is intended to cure a patient of an inherited disease without producing effects that would be passed to future generations. It would involve transplanting genes into a patient's cells to correct an otherwise incurable disease caused by an inborn failure of one or another gene.   The treatment is considered potentially feasible for a few rare but deadly diseases, including profound defects of the immune defense system, in which the faulty gene is known and its normal counterpart has been grown in the laboratory. Far broader applications are considered possible if early tests demonstrate the workability of the technique, which involves the body cells and is thus known by researchers as somatic cell therapy.
lead_paragraph: The first national guidelines for the conduct of human gene therapy have been published by the National Institutes of Health and are expected to have an immediate effect on research groups preparing for tests of this revolutionary form of treatment.

abstract: THE policy question concerning human gene therapy is no longer whether to attempt such treatments, but when trials in patients should begin, according to a report released yesterday by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.     Gene therapy designed to treat individual patients without causing changes that could be inherited is just an extension of conventional medical science and technology and does not raise new ethical issues, the report said.    ''The factor that most distinguishes it from other medical technologies is its conspicuousness in the public eye,'' the report said. Some critics have asserted that such treatments would be the beginning of misguided attempts to redesign the human race.
lead_paragraph: THE policy question concerning human gene therapy is no longer whether to attempt such treatments, but when trials in patients should begin, according to a report released yesterday by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

headline.main: AGENCY REPORTS GENETIC THERAPY IS NEAR
headline.print_headline: AGENCY REPORTS GENETIC THERAPY IS NEAR

abstract: AN unusual group of viruses, never implicated in human illness during more than a half century of study, have now been linked to three important diseases: cancer, the acquired immune deficiency syndrome and, most recently, hepatitis.     These viruses are called retroviruses. Some of them have been known since the early 1900's as causes of cancers in chickens and other animals. They have been much-studied over the years because of the clues they offer to the nature of cancer and even to the basic organization of life.
lead_paragraph: AN unusual group of viruses, never implicated in human illness during more than a half century of study, have now been linked to three important diseases: cancer, the acquired immune deficiency syndrome and, most recently, hepatitis.

headline.print_headline: ODD VIRUS NOW LINKED TO MAJOR DISEASES

abstract: The chief Federal advisory panel on gene splicing policy today unanimously rejected a proposal to ban all gene transplantations from one mammalian species to another.    The panel's resolution said such research is important and offers long- term possibilities for treatment of human and animal disease as well as the development of more efficient food sources.    These potential benefits ''make it a moral imperative that we strongly oppose the blanket prohibition of this class of experiments,'' the resolution by the Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee said.    The panel advises the National Institutes of Health on policy matters related to recombinant DNA technology, known popularly as gene splicing and in some of its aspects as genetic engineering.
lead_paragraph: The chief Federal advisory panel on gene splicing policy today unanimously rejected a proposal to ban all gene transplantations from one mammalian species to another.

keywords.value: Humane Society of the United States

abstract: New attempts to treat incurable human genetic disease by transplanting genes will probably be made within three years, an expert said here today.    The prediction, by Dr. C. Thomas Caskey of Baylor College of Medicine, was an indication of how far research toward the goal of human gene therapy has progressed in recent years. Dr. Caskey said research workers were optimistic that the time is approaching for trials of such treatment in humans.   Although the attempts at gene transfer will be made in the hope of curing disease, Dr. Caskey said it would be prudent to expect that the first few future attempts might have only limited success. Such efforts would be extremely valuable, he said, in providing insights and data important to making future treatment more effective.
lead_paragraph: New attempts to treat incurable human genetic disease by transplanting genes will probably be made within three years, an expert said here today.

headline.main: NEW EFFORTS TO CURE DISEASE BY GENE THERAPY PREDICTED
headline.print_headline: NEW EFFORTS TO CURE DISEASE BY GENE THERAPY PREDICTED

abstract: SOMEDAY, perhaps as soon as the next decade, scientists will construct largely artificial viruslike particles and use them as vehicles to transplant foreign genes into specific cells within the human body.    These artificial particles - they could almost be called man-made viruses - may be used in sophisticated gene therapy to cure genetic diseases that ruin human lives through the lack or malfunction of single specific genes.   Today, rapid advances are occurring in research aimed at making gene therapy possible. Natural viruses are being modified to act as efficient carriers of the genes, and more and more genes that might usefully be transplanted are being identified and grown in laboratories.   About 3,000 genetic diseases are known, each caused by the failure of one gene, a different one for each disease. Little can be done now for most of these diseases, even though the specific disturbance of the body's chemistry is sometimes well-known.  Genes are essentially long segments of the genetic material DNA that embody the instructions for making specific substances that the living cell needs. Human cells have somewhere between 50,000 and 100,000 such genes. An error in any of them can upset the chemistry of the whole body and produce a grave, even fatal, disease.
lead_paragraph: SOMEDAY, perhaps as soon as the next decade, scientists will construct largely artificial viruslike particles and use them as vehicles to transplant foreign genes into specific cells within the human body.

headline.main: TREATMENT IS NEARING FOR GENETIC DEFECTS
headline.print_headline: TREATMENT IS NEARING FOR GENETIC DEFECTS

abstract: SCIENTISTS are setting out to grow breeds of giant mice that are genetically a little bit human. Dozens of such animals have already been born, each carrying transplanted genes for human growth hormone that makes them grow to twice their normal size.    The aim is better understanding of how genes are controlled, but practical applications are already being pursued including the development of faster growing, better quality beef cattle, that might have immense impact on future agriculture. Moreover, issues have already been raised concerning the ethics of doing similar gene transplantations in humans, although specialists put the prospect of doing this many years in the future because unknowns and technical obstacles are so great.   Some of the new mice are about twice normal size because they carry human genes for the production of growth hormone and have an oversupply of that hormone in their blood. From these animals, scientists hope to breed whole colonies of mice that will pass the human gene to their offspring in the normal course of heredity.
lead_paragraph: SCIENTISTS are setting out to grow breeds of giant mice that are genetically a little bit human. Dozens of such animals have already been born, each carrying transplanted genes for human growth hormone that makes them grow to twice their normal size.

headline.main: ANIMALS GIVEN A HUMAN GENE
headline.print_headline: ANIMALS GIVEN A HUMAN GENE

abstract: THE LOS ALAMOS NATIONAL Laboratory in New Mexico, biophysicist Walter Goad punches a few keys on a computer terminal. Moments later, glowing green type illuminates the monitor in front of him. ''ATGGCTACAGGTAAG . . . '' begins the message, which goes on and on for almost 2,000 repetitions of A, T, C and G. Dr. Goad, director of the Government-sponsored Genetic Sequence Data Bank, known as GenBank, can read the cryptic language easily. It is an example of the genetic code, this particular procession of characters being the recipe for making a specific protein, the hormone that controls human growth.   It will probably take more than three billion characters to encode in this way all the chemicals in the body. One day, Dr. Goad hopes, the complete recipe for a human being will be revealed. ''Man's entire hereditary code should fit on 30 high- density magnetic tapes, taking up less than a four-foot bookshelf.''

abstract: The ability to analyze and manipulate human genetic material is beginning to transform the whole field of diagnosis and treatment of hereditary diseases, scientists have told at a gathering here.   Some of that transformation is already in progress in new techniques for early diagnosis of genetic disorders.   Specialists in genetics predicted at lectures here that the new knowledge would make it possible to treat some genetic diseases that are now incurable. But they said that a great deal remained to be learned and that it was not yet possible to predict when these achievements would occur.
lead_paragraph: The ability to analyze and manipulate human genetic material is beginning to transform the whole field of diagnosis and treatment of hereditary diseases, scientists have told at a gathering here.

headline.print_headline: GENETIC SCIENTISTS HAIL GAINS IN FIELD

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: MARCH OF DIMES BIRTH DEFECTS FOUNDATION

abstract:
While genetic engineering in humans seems close enough to justify public concern, we must not be swept away by fear of exaggerated dangers.

Unfortunately, a broad spectrum of clergymen recently demanded a total ban on attempts at one kind of genetic engineering, germline intervention -that is, insertion of genes into a cell that will become an embryo. It was argued that a distinction cannot be drawn between medical and eugenic uses and that we should not try to eliminate defective genes because we have no right to tamper with evolution.

In contrast to the apocalyptic tone of this discussion, a Presidential commission has realistically analyzed many conceivable dangers. Its excellent report, issued in December, strongly supported the goal of somatic gene therapy - that is, insertion of genes into body cells but not into germ cells (sperm or eggs). But the commission also expressed deep concern about changes perpetuated in future generations, because such intervention would open up the awesome prospect of directing future evolution of the species. The commission did not call for a ban but its position may have encouraged such a call. It is important to examine this evolutionary argument carefully and to identify the real issues.

headline.main: CELLS AND SOULS
headline.print_headline: CELLS AND SOULS

abstract: The rare disease called Lesch-Nyhan syndrome has many devastating effects. They typically include impaired control of physical movements, mental retardation and an uncontrollable urge toward violent self-destruction. Unless restrained, children afflicted with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome will try to gnaw and tear their fingers, lips and any other accessible parts of their bodies. There is no cure for the disease and little effective treatment. Yet the cause is known: Just one of the more than 50,000 genes each human possesses fails to function.
lead_paragraph: The rare disease called Lesch-Nyhan syndrome has many devastating effects. headline.main: Index; International
headline.print_headline: Index; International

abstract: GENETIC diseases are among the most tragic human afflictions, particularly so since the discoveries of modern science have made it clear that a single seemingly minor chemical change in a gene can produce pain, deformity and death.   Recently scientists have performed some remarkable feats of gene manipulation in efforts to learn some of the secrets of the crucial control system that regulates genes, turning normal as well as abnormal genes on and off in answer to the body's need. Included among these feats have been the transplantation of human genes into fertilized animal egg cells so that the foreign genes become incorporated in the developing embryos. The ultimate goal of such research is to someday control or even cure genetic diseases.   More than 2,000 diseases of humans are caused by a single abnormality in one or another single gene which embodies the genetic blueprint for making a single protein. Even though the abnormality may be only a small part of one gene among the many thousands needed to create a human, that departure from normal can produce physical deformity, hormone problems, heart failure, blood that doesn't clot properly or carry oxygen as it should, mental retardation or early death. Sometimes several of those grim effects stem from one genetic error, seemingly minor in its chemistry, but disastrous in its effects.
lead_paragraph: GENETIC diseases are among the most tragic human afflictions, particularly so since the discoveries of modern science have made it clear that a single seemingly minor chemical change in a gene can produce pain, deformity and death.

headline.main: GENE THERAPY: SCIENTISTS TAKE FIRST STEPS TOWARD CURING THE 'INCURABLE' DISORDERS
headline.print_headline: GENE THERAPY: SCIENTISTS TAKE FIRST STEPS TOWARD CURING THE 'INCURABLE' DISORDERS

abstract: The 21-year-old woman has ''gargoyle'' features, short stature and multiple bone deformities that have led to several fractures. In addition, she has hormone deficiencies and chronic heart failure. Her life expectancy today is only about two more years and she is too intelligent to have many illusions about the future.   This grim portrait illustrates the human side of a frontier of medical research called ''gene therapy.'' Despite their variety, the young woman's life-threatening disabilities seem to result from a single defective or missing gene among the many thousands that make up any person's hereditary endowment. The result of that single gene defect is a grave form of anemia - beta zero thalassemia major.
lead_paragraph: The 21-year-old woman has ''gargoyle'' features, short stature and multiple bone deformities that have led to several fractures. lead_paragraph: Early in July, the 10‐man City Council of Cambridge, Mass., at the urging of some concerned Harvard scientists, voted to ask Harvard University to halt temporarily the construction of a new $500,000 laboratory for specialized genetics .research. This move on the part of the Mayor and other local elected officials against the scientific decisions of the university was unprecedented, but so was the dramatic reason for it—the fear that the biologists, who propose to tamper with the genetic apparatus of microorganisms, would create a new Andromeda‐like strain that might escape their control and spread an incurable disease to the population.

headline.print_headline: 2 Doctors Urge a Halt in Human Genetics Engineering

byline.original: By Harold M. Schmeck Jr. Special to The New York Times

abstract: L Edson revs experiment by Drs Merril, Geier and Petricciani in which human cells growing in lab took up and used genetic material native to bacteria, apparently 'curing' cells of serious genetic defect that afflicted person from whom cell was taken; experiment is step towards possibility that inherited genetic disorders can be cured by chemically altering genes; Edson cites related research including that performed by W Szybalski, Dr J Lederberg, R Sinsheimer and Dr J Littlefield; cartoon speculating on possibility of genetic surgery to cure such inherited disorders
snippet: L Edson revs experiment by Drs Merril, Geier and Petricciani in which human cells growing in lab took up and used genetic material native to bacteria, apparently 'curing' cells of serious genetic defect that afflicted person from whom cell was tak...
lead_paragraph: Last year, some 200,000 babies were born in the United States with genetic defects ranging from a cleft lip to mental retardation. Can such inherited disorders be cured by chemically altering the genes? Can we, for instance, replace a defective gene with a good one?

headline.main: Medicine
